fields.headline: How far can they go?
fields.bodyText: DAVID MILIBAND Age: 36 Present job: Minister for Schools Strengths: well connected to Labour's high command, thinker who has grappled with New Labour's over-arching philosophy since the 1990s, highly regarded by Tony Blair. Weaknesses: tendency to policy-wonkery, untested public speaker. Did say: 'Third Way triangulation is much better suited to insurgency than incumbency.' Has never said: 'Forget Europe, fancy a pint?' Future: in Cabinet before the next election, sky's the limit after that. DAVID LAMMY Age: 29 Present job: Minister for Health Strengths: assured public speaker who amazed backbench colleagues with his maiden speech in the House of Commons which was at once self-deprecating and witty. Close to Labour high command. Weaknesses: lacks the political depth of contemporaries, danger that he has been catapulted too quickly into government. Did say: 'Get as much of your teachers' brains as you can, that is a passport to success. That is for free. All you have to do is listen, take it in and you are off.' Has never said: 'What we need is a good old-fashioned dose of socialism.' Future: Possible Cabinet material after next election. Sure to have party conference eating out of his hand after this year's appearance. YVETTE COOPER Age: 33 Present job: Parliamentary Secretary , Lord Chancellor's Department. Strengths: takes women's issues and public health seriously, solid House of Commons performer. Weaknesses: her marriage to Ed Balls, chief economic adviser to Gordon Brown, means she is greeted with suspicion by many departments who think she is a Treasury spy. Public appeal is limited. Did say: 'It's the only way to avoid bow legs from lugging huge bags between London and the constituency.' (On why she has two washing machines) Has never said: 'Gordon acts like he runs the world.' Future: definite Cabinet material after the next election, future as head of one of the big spending departments, probably health. RUTH KELLY Age: 34 Present job: Financial Secretary to the Treasury Strengths: Ultra-loyal,clever Blairite and expert on economic issues, has played a quiet game, taking care not to rock any political boats. Weaknesses: can sound too much like a New Labour automaton. Her conversation was once described as 'sounding as if produced by a central computer'. Did say: 'Feminism tempered by Catholicism.' (On her political philosophy) Has never said: 'Children, I can't stand them.' (She had three in quick succession) Future: first female Chancellor of the Exchequer. ...and how they fit together: David Miliband is the brother of... Ed Miliband who works with... Ed Balls who is married to... Yvette Cooper who studied at Oxford with... Ruth Kelly who is in the Christian Socialist Movement with... David Lammy
